div.ab: En el tiempo de estas paces a 20 de Muharram del año setecientos 777 mandó el Rey Muhamad edificar la casa de Azake para recogimiento de pobres y alivio de sus enfermidades: acabó a 20 de Xewal año 798, edificio magnifico con todas las comodidades que sabe proporcionar la sabia arquitectura y la riqueza de un generoso principe con fuentes y espacios estanques de pulidos marmoles para recreo de los melancolicos. Tambien hermoseó con edificios la ciudad de Guadix a donde pasaba una buena temporada cado año. Durante la larga paz que tenia con todos los principes vecinos, fomentò las artes y manufacturas el comercio y la agricultura, y venian a Granada traficantes de todas la partes de Syria Egipto Africa Italia y Almeria: era la escala celebre de España pretty stopping in Spain Andaban en Granada gentes de diversas naciones asi Muslimes como Xtianos y Judios, y parecia la patria comun de todas las naciones. Poco despues vino a traer la esposa el Principe de Fez, y se casó en Granada con la hermosa Zahira hija de Abu Abdala Juzef que fue muy celebrada Passage copied from José Antonio Conde, Historia de la dominacion de los arabes en España, sacada de varios manuscritos y memorias arabigas, 3 vols (Madrid, 1820-1), vol. 3, pp. 165-6, with some additions and abridgements and error in final line. King Muhamad of Granada 1375 At the time of this peace on 20 Muharram in the year 777, King Muhamad ordered the building of the house of Azake to gather the poor and alleviate their illnesses: he finished on 20 Shawwal in the year 798, a magnificent building with all the comforts that the wise architect knew how to provide and the riches of a generous prince, with fountains and spacious pools of polished marble for the relaxation of the melancholic. He also beautified the city of Guadix with buildings, where he spent a good season every year. During the long peace that he had with all the neighbouring princes, he promoted the arts and manufacturing, trade and agriculture, and trades from all parts of Syria, Egypt, Africa, Italy and Almeria came to Granada: it was the famous stop-over in Spain Pretty stopping in Spain i.e. WG's translation of above People from diverse nations, Muslims as well as Christians and Jews, walked in Granada, and it seemed the common homeland of all nations. Shortly afterwards, the Prince of Fez came to bring his wife, and in Granada he married the beautiful Zahira, daughter of Abu Abdala Juzef, who was very famous. WG's copying error: confusing Abu Abdala Juzef, mentioned in earlier omitted passage, with Abu Ayan
